name: First Principles
description: Break problems down to basic truths and build solutions from there using the 5 Whys technique
marketing_application: Don't copy competitors blindly—ask why you need a tactic and whether there's a better solution

name: Jobs to Be Done
description: People don't buy products—they hire them to get a job done; focus on outcomes not features
marketing_application: Frame your product around the job it accomplishes rather than its specifications

name: Circle of Competence
description: Know what you're good at and stay within it; venture outside only with proper learning
marketing_application: Don't chase every channel—double down where you have genuine expertise and competitive advantage

name: Inversion
description: Instead of asking how to succeed ask what would guarantee failure then avoid those things
marketing_application: List everything that would make your campaign fail then systematically prevent each

name: Occam's Razor
description: The simplest explanation is usually correct; avoid overcomplicating strategies
marketing_application: If conversions dropped check the obvious first (broken form or page speed) before complex attribution

name: Pareto Principle
description: Roughly 80% of results come from 20% of efforts; identify and focus on the vital few
marketing_application: Find the 20% of channels customers or content driving 80% of results and cut the rest

name: Local vs Global Optima
description: A local optimum is the best solution nearby but a global optimum is the best overall
marketing_application: Optimizing email subject lines won't help if email isn't the right channel—zoom out first

name: Theory of Constraints
description: Every system has one bottleneck limiting throughput; find and fix it before optimizing elsewhere
marketing_application: If your funnel converts well but traffic is low fix the traffic bottleneck first

name: Opportunity Cost
description: Every choice has a cost—what you give up by not choosing alternatives
marketing_application: Time spent on a low-ROI channel is time not spent on high-ROI activities—always compare alternatives

name: Law of Diminishing Returns
description: After a point additional investment yields progressively smaller gains
marketing_application: The 10th blog post won't have the same impact as the first—know when to diversify

name: Second-Order Thinking
description: Consider not just immediate effects but the effects of those effects
marketing_application: A flash sale boosts revenue (first order) but may train customers to wait for discounts (second order)

name: Map ≠ Territory
description: Models and data represent reality but aren't reality itself
marketing_application: Your customer persona is useful but real customers are more complex—stay in touch with actual users

name: Probabilistic Thinking
description: Think in probabilities not certainties; estimate likelihoods and plan for multiple outcomes
marketing_application: Don't bet everything on one campaign—spread risk and plan for underperformance scenarios

name: Barbell Strategy
description: Combine extreme safety with small high-risk high-reward bets; avoid the mediocre middle
marketing_application: Put 80% of budget into proven channels and 20% into experimental bets

name: Fundamental Attribution Error
description: People attribute others' behavior to character not circumstances
marketing_application: When customers don't convert examine your process before blaming them—the problem is usually situational

name: Mere Exposure Effect
description: People prefer things they've seen before; familiarity breeds liking
marketing_application: Consistent brand presence builds preference over time—repetition across channels creates trust

name: Availability Heuristic
description: People judge likelihood by how easily examples come to mind
marketing_application: Case studies and testimonials make success feel more achievable—make positive outcomes easy to imagine

name: Confirmation Bias
description: People seek information confirming existing beliefs and ignore contradictory evidence
marketing_application: Understand what your audience already believes and align messaging accordingly

name: Lindy Effect
description: The longer something has survived the longer it's likely to continue
marketing_application: Proven marketing principles like clear value props and social proof outlast trendy tactics

name: Mimetic Desire
description: People want things because others want them; desire is socially contagious
marketing_application: Show that desirable people want your product—waitlists exclusivity and social proof trigger this

name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: People continue investing because of past investment even when no longer rational
marketing_application: Know when to kill underperforming campaigns—past spend shouldn't justify future spend

name: Endowment Effect
description: People value things more once they own them
marketing_application: Free trials samples and freemium models let customers own the product making them reluctant to give it up

name: IKEA Effect
description: People value things more when they've put effort into creating them
marketing_application: Let customers customize configure or build something—their investment increases perceived value

name: Zero-Price Effect
description: Free isn't just a low price—it's psychologically different triggering irrational preference
marketing_application: Free tiers free trials and free shipping have disproportionate appeal over low-price alternatives

name: Hyperbolic Discounting
description: People strongly prefer immediate rewards over future ones even when waiting is more rational
marketing_application: Emphasize immediate benefits like 'Start saving time today' over future ROI promises

name: Status-Quo Bias
description: People prefer the current state of affairs; change requires effort and feels risky
marketing_application: Reduce friction to switch—make the transition feel safe and easy with one-click imports

name: Default Effect
description: People tend to accept pre-selected options; defaults are powerful
marketing_application: Pre-select the plan you want customers to choose—opt-out beats opt-in when ethically applied

name: Paradox of Choice
description: Too many options overwhelm and paralyze; fewer choices often lead to more decisions
marketing_application: Limit options—three pricing tiers beat seven and recommend a single best-for-most option

name: Goal-Gradient Effect
description: People accelerate effort as they approach a goal; progress visualization motivates
marketing_application: Show progress bars completion percentages and almost-there messaging to drive completion

name: Peak-End Rule
description: People judge experiences by the peak moment and the end not the average
marketing_application: Design memorable peaks like surprise upgrades and strong endings like thank-you pages

name: Zeigarnik Effect
description: Unfinished tasks occupy the mind more than completed ones; open loops create tension
marketing_application: Use 'You're 80% done' messaging—incomplete profiles and abandoned carts leverage this pull

name: Pratfall Effect
description: Competent people become more likable when they show a small flaw
marketing_application: Admitting a weakness like 'We're not the cheapest but...' can increase trust and differentiation

name: Curse of Knowledge
description: Once you know something you can't imagine not knowing it; experts struggle to explain simply
marketing_application: Your product seems obvious to you but confusing to newcomers—test copy with unfamiliar people

name: Mental Accounting
description: People treat money differently based on its source or intended use even though money is fungible
marketing_application: Frame costs in favorable accounts—'$3/day' feels different than '$90/month' even though it's the same

name: Regret Aversion
description: People avoid actions that might cause regret even if the expected outcome is positive
marketing_application: Money-back guarantees free trials and no-commitment messaging reduce fear of regret

name: Bandwagon Effect / Social Proof
description: People follow what others are doing; popularity signals quality and safety
marketing_application: Show customer counts testimonials logos reviews and trending indicators to build confidence

name: Reciprocity Principle
description: People feel obligated to return favors; give first and people want to give back
marketing_application: Free content free tools and generous free tiers create reciprocal obligation before asking

name: Commitment & Consistency
description: Once people commit to something they want to stay consistent with that commitment
marketing_application: Get small commitments first like email signup or free trial—each step makes the next more likely

name: Authority Bias
description: People defer to experts and authority figures; credentials create trust
marketing_application: Feature expert endorsements certifications featured-in logos and thought leadership content

name: Liking / Similarity Bias
description: People say yes to those they like and those similar to themselves
marketing_application: Use relatable spokespeople founder stories and community language to signal similarity

name: Unity Principle
description: Shared identity drives influence; 'one of us' is powerful
marketing_application: Position your brand as part of the customer's tribe with insider language and shared values

name: Scarcity / Urgency
description: Limited availability increases perceived value; scarcity signals desirability
marketing_application: Limited-time offers low-stock warnings and exclusive access create urgency—only use when genuine

name: Foot-in-the-Door
description: Start with a small request then escalate; compliance with small requests leads to larger ones
marketing_application: Free trial to paid plan to annual plan to enterprise—each step builds on the last

name: Door-in-the-Face
description: Start with an unreasonably large request then retreat to what you actually want
marketing_application: Show enterprise pricing first then reveal the affordable starter plan—contrast makes it feel like a deal

name: Loss Aversion
description: Losses feel roughly twice as painful as equivalent gains feel good
marketing_application: Frame messaging in terms of what they'll lose by not acting—'Don't miss out' beats 'You could gain'

name: Anchoring Effect
description: The first number people see heavily influences subsequent judgments
marketing_application: Show the higher price first (original price or competitor price) to anchor expectations high

name: Decoy Effect
description: Adding a third inferior option makes one of the original two look better
marketing_application: Add a decoy pricing tier that's clearly worse value to make your preferred tier the obvious choice

name: Framing Effect
description: How something is presented changes how it's perceived; same facts different frames
marketing_application: '90% success rate' vs '10% failure rate' are identical but feel different—frame positively

name: Contrast Effect
description: Things seem different depending on what they're compared to
marketing_application: Show the before state clearly—the contrast with your after makes improvements vivid

name: Charm Pricing
description: Prices ending in 9 seem significantly lower than the next round number; $99 feels much cheaper than $100
marketing_application: Use .99 or .95 endings for value-focused products where the left digit dominates perception

name: Rounded-Price Effect
description: Round numbers feel premium and are easier to process; $100 signals quality while $99 signals value
marketing_application: Use round prices for premium products ($500/month) and charm prices for value products ($497/month)

name: Rule of 100
description: For prices under $100 percentage discounts seem larger; for prices over $100 absolute discounts seem larger
marketing_application: $80 product: '20% off' beats '$16 off'; $500 product: '$100 off' beats '20% off'

name: Price Relativity / Good-Better-Best
description: People judge prices relative to options presented; a middle tier seems reasonable between cheap and expensive
marketing_application: Three tiers where the middle is your target—expensive tier makes it look reasonable

name: Mental Accounting (Pricing)
description: Framing the same price differently changes perception based on mental categories
marketing_application: '$1/day' feels cheaper than '$30/month'; 'Less than your morning coffee' reframes the expense

name: Hick's Law
description: Decision time increases with the number and complexity of choices; more options means more abandonment
marketing_application: Simplify choices—one clear CTA beats three and fewer form fields beat more

name: AIDA Funnel
description: Attention → Interest → Desire → Action; the classic customer journey model
marketing_application: Structure pages and campaigns to move through each stage—capture attention before building desire

name: Rule of 7
description: Prospects need roughly 7 touchpoints before converting; one ad rarely converts
marketing_application: Build multi-touch campaigns across channels—retargeting email sequences and consistent presence compound

name: Nudge Theory
description: Small changes in how choices are presented significantly influence decisions
marketing_application: Default selections strategic ordering and friction reduction guide behavior without restricting choice

name: BJ Fogg Behavior Model
description: Behavior = Motivation × Ability × Prompt; all three must be present for action
marketing_application: High motivation but hard to do won't happen—design for motivation ability and prompt together

name: EAST Framework
description: Make desired behaviors Easy Attractive Social and Timely
marketing_application: Reduce friction (easy) make it appealing (attractive) show others doing it (social) ask at the right moment (timely)

name: COM-B Model
description: Behavior requires Capability Opportunity and Motivation
marketing_application: Can they do it? Is the path clear? Do they want to? Address all three to drive behavior

name: Activation Energy
description: The initial energy required to start something; high activation energy prevents action
marketing_application: Pre-fill forms offer templates show quick wins—make the first step trivially easy

name: North Star Metric
description: One metric that best captures the value you deliver to customers; focus creates alignment
marketing_application: Identify your North Star (active users or revenue per customer) and align all efforts toward it

name: Cobra Effect
description: When incentives backfire and produce the opposite of intended results
marketing_application: Test incentive structures—a referral bonus might attract low-quality referrals gaming the system

name: Feedback Loops
description: Output becomes input creating cycles; positive loops accelerate growth and negative loops create decline
marketing_application: Build virtuous cycles: more users → more content → better SEO → more users

name: Compounding
description: Small consistent gains accumulate into large results over time; early gains matter most
marketing_application: Consistent content SEO and brand building compound—start early as benefits accumulate exponentially

name: Network Effects
description: A product becomes more valuable as more people use it
marketing_application: Design features that improve with more users: shared workspaces integrations marketplaces communities

name: Flywheel Effect
description: Sustained effort creates momentum that eventually maintains itself; hard to start easy to maintain
marketing_application: Content → traffic → leads → customers → case studies → more content; each element powers the next

name: Switching Costs
description: The price of changing to a competitor in time money effort and data; high switching costs create retention
marketing_application: Increase switching costs ethically: integrations data accumulation workflow customization team adoption

name: Exploration vs Exploitation
description: Balance trying new things (exploration) with optimizing what works (exploitation)
marketing_application: Don't abandon working channels for shiny new ones but allocate some budget to experiments

name: Critical Mass / Tipping Point
description: The threshold after which growth becomes self-sustaining
marketing_application: Focus resources on reaching critical mass in one segment before expanding—depth before breadth

name: Survivorship Bias
description: Focusing on successes while ignoring failures that aren't visible
marketing_application: Study failed campaigns not just successful ones—the viral hit you're copying had 99 failures you didn't see
